------=_NextPart_000_009B_01C87AB7.3D2B2260
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Christofer,
 
I think the modular approach is not always the best or correct approach.  
 
In the case of 3-coupled (or more), non-linear, undirected systems,
solutions exist but are not solvable with deterministic (analytic) methods.
 
We look for attractor basins (even if they are strange attractors) and limit
cycles to narrow an asymptotic search for network system solutions.  Notice
that solutions to various experiments (e.g double pole balancing) are
sensitive to initial conditions. Therefore, solutions sometimes cannot be
anticipated a priori from any subset of component interaction, only from the
total network action/interaction.
 
The best we can do is try and reduce the time for discovering the solution.
 
The 'gravitational' attraction and connection of nodes is not a permanent,
stable condition.  It too is transitory.  This is the foundation of graph
thermodynamics and statistical mechanics.
 
http://barcamp.org/BarCampSantaFeSessions 
 
Ken
 



  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
christofer_fransson
Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 8:18 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Modify NEAT to be more modular...



Dear all,

The human brain has different areas that solve different kind of
problems. My question is if you think it is a good idea to try
encouraging a network to divide a problem into smaller sub problems
and then solve it.

This is my thought:

- Let say that every neuron has 3 coordinates (x,y,z) 
- Assuming that you can tell which neurons were performing well in one
epoch 
(Backprop run, network weights that didn't have to be changed much etc)
- All those nodes should "gravitate" towards each other
- Nodes close to each other have a higher probability to form a
connection.

The result should be a network that in someway tries to be modular.
Next step should be to see if it is possible to do individual training
of different areas of the network.

I mean when you learn math and when you are painting, different areas
of the brain is active.

Comments?

Br,
Christofer
